name: Marriage of private equity and healthcare has a bright future, specialist investor says
introduction: There has never been a better time to raise money for companies in the life sciences sector, according toÂ BenÂ Long, partner at UK-headquartered private equity firm Inflexion.
content:
There has never been a better time to raise money for companies in the life sciences sector, according to Ben Long (pictured), partner at UK-headquartered private equity firm Inflexion.

“Anything with healthcare on it is going to receive a lot of demand from private equity, in particular, because there’s a set pool of capital out there which needs to be invested and, for the last 12 months, really the only sectors where you’ve been able to find certainty, or something close to certainty, have been healthcare and technology,” Mr Long explained.

A rare positive from the pandemic is that it has provided a reminder of the societal value of healthcare, but Mr Long said that the sector’s attractiveness as an investment opportunity had already become evident for firms like his before COVID-19 came along.

"We look at businesses that are generating strong growth, have high margins and have really ambitious management teams"At the moment, Inflexion is invested in five healthcare businesses out of a total portfolio of 52, and Mr Long said that there was an appetite to do more in this space.

One deal that showed Inflexion’s preparedness to make a substantial investment when the right opportunity comes along was last year’s £156 million ($217 million) acquisition of Rosemont Pharmaceuticals, the UK's leading liquid pharmaceuticals business. The business was carved out from US-listed drugmaker Perrigo (NYSE: PRGO), which was seeking to focus on its over-the-counter operations. Inflexion has since invested a further £15 million in business development and the facilities in Leeds.

Other healthcare companies in Inflexion’s portfolio include Pharmaspectra, a provider of medical affairs data to the pharmaceutical and biotech industry, and European LifeCare, which provides travel clinics and public vaccination programs and has had its hands full in recent months delivering parts of the COVID-19 vaccine in Denmark.

So what is it that Inflexion looks for when seeking healthcare companies to invest in?

“We take it case-by-case,” Mr Long said. “We look at businesses that are generating strong growth, have high margins and have really ambitious management teams.

“The areas we’re interested in are niche pharma, pharma services such as companies supplying into the R&D clinical journey and beyond like Pharmaspectra, medical devices, software into the life sciences industry – typically work-flow management tools – and animal health."

Software in life sciences is the hottest area from a private equity perspective at the moment, Mr Long added.

“I think it will continue,” he said. “The pandemic has forced the hands of quite a few stakeholders in the industry to adapt more to digital technologies. If you think about virtual trials and how the regulation has changed around that and how protocol has evolved to take that into account.”

Adding value on top of investment

Mr Long would not be surprised to see plenty of money flooding into the generics sector, either.

“I suspect many economies have had a bit of a wake-up call on the fact that they’re under-investing in healthcare or, at least, the investment should be reallocated to different parts of the healthcare services that they’re providing,” he said. “But it doesn’t necessarily mean there’s any more money to fund healthcare, so there will be some reallocations and I would have thought that the generics market will be a major beneficiary of that.”

In what is a competitive market, private equity firms have to persuade companies that they can add value to the business when they become a shareholder.

Inflexion, for example, helps companies to expand technologically and geographically through its in-house digital teams and international offices, and employs former headhunters to build on the personnel front.

Also important to what Inflexion does are its sector experts within healthcare and a commercial specialist to advise on improving companies’ sales operations, and it helps firms to grow through mergers and acquisitions (M&A).

'Huge opportunity'

Examples of this input include, on the human resources side, Inflexion sourcing a chief financial officer for Rosemont to help structure the business for rapid growth, and supporting on the technology elements of the carve out. There may also be opportunities to drive digital marketing, including through improving its remote communications with healthcare practitioners.

Being able to make changes and wanting to grow rapidly is something that Inflexion looks for when assessing investment opportunities.

“Inflexion is an organization that is run by some extremely ambitious individuals; that seeps all the way down through the team, and we like to see that mirrored in the teams that we’re working with," Mr Long said.

The fact that healthcare is such a booming space at the moment, coupled with the growing realization that it can be a good match with private equity, can only be good news for both.

Mr Long said: “Private equity, as a percentage of total deals – the number of transactions in M&A markets in Europe – is about 8% within healthcare, and across all sectors, it’s about 25%. So there’s a huge penetration opportunity that means if you’re an Inflexion or another specialist investor in the healthcare space, there are plenty of companies to invest in.”
